questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings. Which of the following stridor is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inspiratory stridor

The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy Image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antral sign

The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

The given clinical scenario along with type B tympanometry curve is suggestive of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Laryngocele

The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

questions.text: Given below is the endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity. Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Inferior Turbinate

The marked structure is the lowermost projection in the lateral wall of the nose, the inferior turbinate. The middle turbinate is seen as superior to it.
The lateral wall of the nose contains three or sometimes four projections of variable size namely superior, middle, and inferior turbinates along with a corresponding meatus under each turbinate. The inferior turbinate is the largest turbinate and occupies the lower third of the lateral nasal wall. It is a separate bone. Middle and superior turbínates are ethmoturbinal, part of the ethmoid bone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with multiple nodules in the nasal mucosa. Biopsy from the nodules revealed the presence of Miculikz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rhinoscleroma

The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings showing Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by plasma cells. Histology also shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes and eosinophils

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Quinsy

The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with a normal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil and tonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highly suggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fossa of Rosenmuller

The image shown is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of the nasophary the fossa of Rosenmuller. The nasopharynx is present above the soft palate and is made up of the ro lateral walls.

questions.text: The following instrument is useful in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anterior rhinoscopy

The above is a thudicum nasal speculum. It is used to part the ala so as to visualize the anterior part of the nasal cavity. Structures visualized on Anterior rhinoscopy are:

Septum, Lateral wall (Middle and inferior turbinate), Floor

Posterior rhinoscopy is done using a St. Clair Thompson's Posterior rhinoscopy mirror through the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Schwartze sign 

The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis.

questions.text: A child with protruding ears as shown is brought to the OPD by his worried parents. They opt for surgical correction of the defect due to cosmetic reasons. After what age would you proceed with the surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

6 years

Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years.

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone

The instrument seen in the image is Walsham forceps. It is is mainly used to reduce nasal bone fracture.

questions.text: The test shown in the image is used to detect the abnormality of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nasal valve

The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is used to detect abnormalities of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman came with complaints of progressive hearing loss and tinnitus for a few weeks. Pure tone audiometry was done as shown below. Which of the following phenomenon is seen in the above patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Paracusis willisii

The clinical scenario of pregnant women presenting with progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and pure tone audiometry showing Carhart’s notch is suggestive of Otosclerosis. Paracusis willisii is seen in patients with stapedial otosclerosis. An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. The louder voice is better transmitted through the fixed stapes. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis willisii.

choices.text: Males are affected more commonly than females

questions.text: A 38-year-old housewife presents with facial weakness on the right side, difficulty in closing the right eye, and loss of taste sensation. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Males are affected more commonly than females

Bell’s palsy affects both males and females equally. It is an acute onset idiopathic ipsilateral LMN facial nerve palsy. Most of the evidence supports the viral etiology due to herpes simplex, herpes zoster, or the Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Reinke's edema 

The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of a sudden loss of taste and hearing loss. He also says he is unable to close one eye and tears do not stop flowing. On examination, there are lesions In the ear as shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ramsay Hunt syndrome 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus infection that results in inflammation of the geniculate ganglion of cranial nerve VII. Ramsay Hunt is a clinical diagnosis and classically is described as a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, otalgia, and vesicles near the ear and auditory canal. Diagnosis is often missed or delayed, which can lead to an increased incidence of long-term complications. The condition is self-limiting, but treatment is targeted at decreasing the total duration of the illness as well as providing analgesia and preventing the complications that can occur.

questions.text: A patient undergoes indirect laryngoscopy as a part of his routine ENT examination. The laryngoscopy image is given below. Identify the structure marked as A:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pyriform fossa 

The pyriform sinus (also piriform recess, piriform sinus, piriform fossa, or smuggler's fossa) is a small recess on either side of the laryngeal inlet. It is bounded medially by the aryepiglottic fold, and laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane. The fossae are involved in speech

questions.text: Which of the following x-ray view is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Caldwell's view 

The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph, with its posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits. This view aids in visualizing the paranasal sinuses, especially the frontal sinus. It can help to assess inflammatory conditions such as sinusitis and secondary osteomyelitis, and sinus polyps or cysts.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient presents with hearing loss and tinnitus for the last several years. The hearing loss has been worsening while the tinnitus is pulsatile. Otoscopy reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glomus tumor 

This clinical scenario with progressive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus for several weeks, and a red mass behind an intact tympanic membrane are suggestive of glomus tumor.
